pages.body:
Renesas Design System

Renesas Design System

The Renesas Design System is a comprehensive collection of reusable components, guidelines, and assets that enable our team to create consistent, scalable design solutions for renesas.com. It provides a unified set of standards, principles, and best practices for both designers and developers. As the single source of truth for design and usability, it ensures alignment across teams and supports efficient, user-centered product development.

Explore componentsImplementation guide

Current version

v1.0.0-preview

Includes refreshed foundations, accessible components, and our Drupal starter kit


Changelog coverage

1 releases

Historic entries and release notes are captured below so teams can adopt updates with confidence.

Changelog

Every update to tokens, foundations, or components ships with context and guidance.

v1.0.0-preview

Initial preview release covering six core components, token pipeline, and Drupal bridge scaffolding.

Core team

Reach out for onboarding, design pairing, accessibility reviews, and roadmap planning.

Jordan Lee

Lead UX Designer

jordan.lee@virtualds.com

Priya Menon

Design Ops Partner

priya.menon@virtualds.com

Diego Martins

Lead UX Engineer

diego.martins@virtualds.com

Contribution model

We partner with teams to keep the system cohesive, accessible, and ready for production.

  1. 1Open a proposal in GitHub using the RFC template with problem framing and desired outcomes.
  2. 2Prototype alongside the design system core team to validate accessibility, interaction, and visual fit.
  3. 3Partner with engineering peers to align code standards, tokens, and test coverage.
  4. 4Ship with documentation updates, usage guidance, and a changelog entry so teams can adopt confidently.

Contribution model

We partner with teams to keep the system cohesive, accessible, and ready for production.

  1. 1Open a proposal in GitHub using the RFC template with problem framing and desired outcomes.
  2. 2Prototype alongside the design system core team to validate accessibility, interaction, and visual fit.
  3. 3Partner with engineering peers to align code standards, tokens, and test coverage.
  4. 4Ship with documentation updates, usage guidance, and a changelog entry so teams can adopt confidently.
